messageBody:
How does this work in practice? Do you need to change your ClassLoader to
load Mock B instead of B? If not how would create a suite of tests - one
which tests real B, and one which tests A using Mock B?

Thanks

Matt

From: ghouston@...

Sent: 30/05/01 20:09
Subject: [junit] Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methods

If your method chains are too long, use Mock objects to limit the
depth of interaction.

example...

A calls B, B then calls C, C then calls E. E returns to C, C
returns to B, B returns to A.

if you want to just test A, then create a Mock of B. The Mock of B
will just validate it was called, and return. In the test, replace B
with Mock B. So the test looks like...

A calls Mock B, Mock B returns to A

This way you are only testing A and it's interaction with B. It also
helps with maintiance of your unit tests. Without the Mock B,
anytime C or E changes, you are likely to need to change your test.
With the mock object, the test is no longer dependent of C and E.

- Greg

> If your method chains are so large its hard to pinpoint the problem
when a unit
> test fails, then perhaps some refactoring is in order to break up
the chain. A
> method call should generally perform one discreet action. In
almost every
> application I've seen where hard-to-find bugs are causing problems,
many of them
> could be reduced by making the methods smaller, and having more of
them. As
> long as each method does one well-defined thing, and is sensibly
named, having
> more small methods will cause less confusion than having methods
that are 300
> lines long.
